      • DavidFriedman says:
        May 18, 2020 at 1:13 pm

        Already global warming is happening.

        Global warming is happening. So far the serious negative effects it is supposed to cause are not. Crop yields continue to go up, not down. Hurricanes have not increased in frequency.

        And the President of the US doesn’t even believe in global warming. And that’s true of lots of people and politicians in lots of countries.

        It’s hard to tell what politicians believe in. My conjecture is that Putin believes in global warming but also believes, probably correctly, that Russia, much of which is cold, will benefit by it.

        I have no idea what Trump believes and am unlikely to find out from what he says, on that subject or most others.

        Log in to Reply
    • Erusian says:
      May 18, 2020 at 7:01 am

      Whenever I point that there are no children out there who are adoptable, they point me at all the children that are in sub-optimal foster homes. The very reason that these children are in foster care is because they are either too old or not adoptable.

      “Too old” is glossing over a lot. There’s an entire population of perfectly healthy children, mentally sound children who simply aren’t very young (say, three years old or younger) who largely don’t get adopted. This represents a chronic group who usually age out of the system and do poorly because the system is optimized around babies going out the door, not providing care until you’re eighteen.

      More generally, climate anti-natalists seem to be regurgitating a form of Malthusian Theory in economics and population control advocacy.

      Log in to Reply
      • ana53294 says:
        May 18, 2020 at 7:14 am

        Sure, but telling people not to have biological chidren is not going to make it much more likely that those children get adopted.

        And from the families I’ve observed, I haven’t seen children under six who are healthy (or at least not heart-breakingly sick) and not that disabled being available for adoption and not getting adopted.

        But yes, “too old” usually means “old enough to remember their parents as something more than a very foggy memory”.

        Log in to Reply
        • Erusian says:
          May 18, 2020 at 8:14 am

          I suppose the cut off might be six rather than three but that doesn’t change the point. It jives with their point that there are people who need help now that are neglected. Not that I find the argument convincing: I’d prefer other measures. Still, I’d push back against erasing those orphans. There’s a vast gulf between, “all orphans get adopted” and “all orphans anyone wants to adopt get adopted.”

          Log in to Reply
          • ana53294 says:
            May 18, 2020 at 8:32 am

            All orphans who offer a close enough experience to biological parenting are adopted.

            So you can’t get the experience of raising a child and marvelling at their development (first steps, first words, first smile, rolling around, etc), with the children unwanted.

            And people who want to be parents want to be parents, not something else.

          • Erusian says:
            May 18, 2020 at 9:33 am

            And people who want to be parents want to be parents, not something else.

            What is someone who adopts a twelve year old orphan, since it’s “something else” and not a parent?

            I understand what you’re saying: people want very young children that don’t remember their birth parents. But there’s a weird insistence on ignoring orphans who aren’t very young going on, to the point of delegitimizing families that are formed by adopting them.

          • ana53294 says:
            May 18, 2020 at 10:09 am

            Heroes or saints. I’m not trying to diminish the people who adopt older kids and love and care for them; it’s just that not everybody can be a hero. Most people are ordinary and want the ordinary effort and payoffs of being a parent, not heroism.

          • Aapje says:
            May 18, 2020 at 3:36 pm

            @Erusian

            It’s not merely not remembering their birth parents. Older adoptees often have serious issues trusting their new parents.

    • Mark V Anderson says:
      May 18, 2020 at 6:53 pm

      Thanks Ana for the interesting post. My wife and I adopted kids 25-30 years ago. It does sound like it is getting harder, though it was not easy back then. We adopted internationally because it was very difficult to find kids in the US. We were matched with a kid after about a year each time. The first one took about 2 1/2 years to bring home because lots of legal issues at the Indian adoption agency, but only about 6 months the 2nd time. Both of them have been very good kids, no complaints.

      If I can believe this link, it appears to take an average of one to two years now, but maybe more uncertain than in the past. I suspect the difficulty is mostly political issues. I bet there are enough orphaned kids in very poor countries that there would be enough babies for everyone who wanted to adopt a kid, but politicians are playing games with these kids’ lives. Maybe not in the countries we used to get them from, such as Korea and China, because those countries are richer, but I bet in Africa, Pakistan, Bangladesh.

      By the way , it appears to be true that there are still kids available to adopt if older kids are taken. But I have heard that once kids in abusive environments reach 3 or 4, they become very difficult to parent. And remember, most of these potential adopters have never been parents before, so they have no idea how good they will be at parenting. It is a very large risk to adopt an older child when you don’t know if you can handle it. Maybe parents will do that if they have no other choice.

      Log in to Reply
      • Aapje says:
        May 19, 2020 at 4:58 am

        I bet there are enough orphaned kids in very poor countries that there would be enough babies for everyone who wanted to adopt a kid

        That seems very unlikely since very many fraud cases were exposed, cases where foreign orphanages paid traffickers for babies, cases where parents were told lies (for example, that the kids would get an education and would then be returned to their family), etc.

        This suggests that the number of actually orphaned kids that are available for adoption is already below demand, let alone if way more people would seek to adopt.

        Log in to Reply
        • Matt M says:
          May 19, 2020 at 6:13 am

          And as far as I can tell, the vast majority of countries are very much against the adoption of “their” orphans by foreigners. As a matter of official policy, at least.

          Log in to Reply
        • zoozoc says:
          May 19, 2020 at 2:30 pm

          I think what is important to know is that in many countries, there aren’t truly “orphans” as they still have living family who may be taking care of them (at least somewhat). Most places that are underdeveloped have a very communal and tribal culture and so the concept of an orphan that has no one to care for them is not true. Of course many of those places are extremely poor too and children may be malnourished.

          Also, many places may be willing to give up children even if there is a parent/guardian who can take care of them because they think they will get a better chance at life in another country. So there can be perverse incentives on both sides of things.

          Log in to Reply
        • Mark V Anderson says:
          May 19, 2020 at 5:58 pm

          That seems very unlikely since very many fraud cases were exposed, cases where foreign orphanages paid traffickers for babies, cases where parents were told lies

          Do you have cites for this? “Very many” is most likely media hype, and and there have really been only a few. Similar to the hype about Blacks killed by police. In any case, that in no way proves that kids available are below demand. When politicians are purposefully keeping actual orphans off the market, that lowers the supply, regardless of whether it would be a good thing for the orphans. One of the issues I had getting my first kid was a judge in India who was bound and determined to slow down the process. He was apparently one of those people who thought it was a bad thing to send Indian babies to the US even though they could find no Indian parents to take them.

          zoozoc, do you have evidence this is true? I think you are right to some extent, although I am pretty sure there are actual orphanages in every poor country, because rich country NGOs set them up. That’s where we got both of our kids from India, which is still a pretty poor country, and more so back in the ’90’s. Although I have a friend who adopted from Brazil about the same time we did, and there does seem to be a family in Brazil that her adopted child came from, who still ask her for money. So I’m not sure how prevalent it is.

          Log in to Reply
          • Aapje says:
            May 20, 2020 at 1:24 am

            My strong impression is that when reporters start investigating, fraud cases pop up left and right. For example, at one time a quarter of US adoptions came from Ethiopia and when they investigated, it was a mess.

            Same for China. As the article notes, China was up to their usual chinanigans of hiding misdeeds.

            In general, there is a financial incentive to look away and typically a political incentive to shut adoption down (since citizens tend to feel protective of ‘their’ youths). The result seems to be a common pattern of denial followed by international adoptions being ended completely from a certain country.

            Perhaps there is sufficient supply if all countries would allow international adoptions according to strict procedures, assuming that this is even possible in all countries (almost certainly not). Otherwise any increase in demand in either going to run into a deficit of babies or will increase fraud cases (or both).

          • Mark V Anderson says:
            May 20, 2020 at 6:14 pm

            @Aajpe.
            I read both of the articles you linked. Yes there are some stolen babies in the adoption market, but those articles in no way indicate there are “very many.” It is true that there is much incentive to steal babies in the 3rd world to supply the market, since many in the 1st world are ready to spend thousands of dollars to find a child, which is tons of money in very poor countries. I am sure that there are some stolen babies, but have seen little evidence that it constitutes a majority, or even a large minority of cases. Even when we were adopting, I had the impression that the Indian agencies were milking us for money, but I don’t think either of our kids were taken from families.

    • Filareta says:
      May 19, 2020 at 1:28 am

      If you take into consideration how much beliefs are heritable (in cultural way, but also in genetic way – even such things as political ideology), abstaining from having kids is actually one of the worst things you could do to environment.

      If someone is so willing to sacrifice for the environment, that he/she can even decide not to have children for it (in a honest way, not simply rationalizing a decision already taken and seeking an excuse not to abandon unfamilial lifestyle), than he/she really, really, really should have children. For the enviroment.

      Log in to Reply
      • Kaitian says:
        May 19, 2020 at 1:43 am

        Only if you assume that it’s common for environmentally conscious people to have a net beneficial impact on the environment. If the best you can hope for is “carbon neutral”, then not having children is still better.

        The next generation will be worse for the environment on a per person basis, but there’ll still be fewer of them to worry about.
        And if you adopt (or otherwise get heavily involved in rearing children who aren’t biologically yours), you have all the benefits of raising a green child without having to create one.

        Log in to Reply
  48. Ghatanathoah says:
    May 18, 2020 at 1:38 am

    I am still struggling with OCD around futurism-related issues. For instance, I keep obsessing on variations of the idea that if the universe is a simulation I will do something that will be the “straw that breaks the camel’s back” in terms of computational intensity. For example, I recently rescued a dog and I keep getting this thought in my head that the Simulators are going to say “What do you mean we have to keep simulating one extra dog brain! That’s it, pull the plug.” I obviously have similar fears about having children. It is very hard to get out of this train of thought, even though I know that, regardless of what odds I should assign the Simulation Hypothesis, I should assign fantastically low odds to the idea that some fairly mundane thing I do will be the thing that makes the simulation too intensive for the simulators (it might be bad for me to keep seeking reassurance online, but I’d appreciate reassurance in this case). This is especially ridiculous when I imagine it in the context of Rescue Simulations, where I find myself positing simulators who are altruistic enough to make such a simulation, but cheap and stingy enough that a few extra baseline humans and animals is just too much for them. (have read Scott’s “Don’t Fear the Simulators,” it is somewhat helpful to reread it, but not enough)

    I am aware that the reason I am worrying so much about this is that I have OCD. It has taken two OCD fears I have, “Existential Risk” and “Something Bad Happening to my Dog,” and fused them together into one super-obsessive fear. I think I probably have a form of OCD that normally manifests as religious obsessions, but since I am not religious it instead focuses on things like The Future of Humanity since that is something I find meaningful. This is frustrating because I love the ideas I have absorbed from places like Less Wrong and SSC, and when I am not in an OCD spiral they are something positive in my life. I want to be able to ponder these ideas again without having my brain twist them into something scary, or throw a fit if I can’t answer all the major problems of science and philosophy.

    Another thought that crossed my mind recently was the idea that a civilization that could build a Rescue Simulation might also be able to figure out how other inhabited worlds in Everett’s many worlds were unable to build a rescue simulation and build rescue simulations of them. I became worried about the idea that doing that might be too much, even for a civilization that could do that. I considered the idea of them somehow acausally trading with their counterparts in other worlds to try to split the work, I don’t know if that would be enough or not. I started fixating on the idea that there might be too people many for them to try, which of course triggered that fear I had earlier about being the straw that breaks the camel’s back for computational intensity. I also worried that they might try and end up running out of memory and not be able to run all the people they recover.

    I know I am being ridiculous (even though I know this I will probably feel better if other people tell me). There are so many unknown factors and I should not worry about such far-out scenarios. No one knows what the limitations on future technology like this will be, or what transhuman civilizations will be able to do. Maybe they will be able to reconstruct people without having to make fully conscious simulations of them first. But telling myself that does not work because my brain just replies that the multiverse is so vast it doesn’t matter how unlikely it is. Ugh.

    I want to be able to contemplate far-out futurist ideas for fun again. I want them to stop triggering anxiety. I remember how much fun they were before my OCD developed, and sometimes when it is inactive they are still fun.

    On an unrelated note, I have noticed that my OCD often seems to get better late at night. A feeling of serenity overcomes me and everything I was obsessively worrying about seems silly and small. Does anyone know why that might happen, or what I can do to get it to happen during the day?

    Log in to Reply
    • Kaitian says:
      May 18, 2020 at 2:33 am

      That honestly does sound a lot like a mental health issue / unhealthy thought patterns, so it’s not something you can reason yourself out of. If you have a therapist, you might want to talk about this with them. If not, I’d recommend stepping away from the whole topic for a few months, consciously not reading or thinking about it. Maybe take up a new hobby or interest to fill the time.

      For a while I had really bad health anxiety that only got worse the more I researched about it. What helped was when I decided not to research any more health topics, and just do some of the things I was afraid of. The anxiety went away after a while and now I can read about the topic again without triggering it.

      Log in to Reply
      • DNM says:
        May 18, 2020 at 12:21 pm

        Note: in my non-trivial amount of experience it is extremely difficult to find a therapist who can even start to follow some of these thought spirals. If I could somehow search for therapists who are nerds or who have STEM undergrad degrees maybe I could get somewhere. I am considering switching to a therapist who has specialty treating those with ASD even though that is not among my diagnoses, just on the hopes that person will be more accustomed to some of the kinds of things I get hung up on.

        Log in to Reply
      • Ghatanathoah says:
        May 18, 2020 at 6:29 pm

        Thank you. I know seeking reassurance is probably not effective in the long run, it is just so hard to not do it! I have been trying to behave normally and not spend as much time ruminating and researching. If I feel the need to I remind myself that often it is more productive to take a break from thinking and let your subconscious work on it.

        It’s hard to avoid the topic because my mind is good at free association, but I can try. I do worry that if I avoid triggering topics my mind will get triggered by more and more things until I avoid everything.

        Log in to Reply
        • Kaitian says:
          May 18, 2020 at 11:30 pm

          If that happens, you still have the option to go to therapy. Maybe the new anxiety-causing topic will be more relatable to the average therapist!

          It’s not so much about completely avoiding any thought if the topic, more like, when you see an article about it on the internet, close the tab and watch a cat video instead. When you feel like googling the offending topic, don’t. And do as much of the stereotypical “go outside / meet friends (stick to phone calls for now) / exercise” as is practical for you.

          Log in to Reply
    • Brassfjord says:
      May 18, 2020 at 3:18 am

      Maybe it will help you to read my reasons for not believing we are in a simulation, here.

      There you can also see that you don’t have to worry about reaching a capacity limit for the simulation. Any simulation must be a Potemkin village to some degree, so if you’re coming close to what it can handle, the simulator can just adjust that degree (e g make a new person an avatar instead of a conscious being).

      You can make your own simulated universe that even reaches technological singularity, without breaking the simulation we’re in, because it will only look like a real simulation to you. You experience that with the same band width as usual, so our Simulator can just fake it.

      Log in to Reply
      • 10240 says:
        May 18, 2020 at 3:26 am

        Any simulation must be a Potemkin village to some degree

        That’s not true if the “outer” universe is vastly bigger than ours, such that it’s feasible to genuinely simulate our entire universe in it.

        Log in to Reply
        • Faza (TCM) says:
          May 18, 2020 at 4:00 am

          That’s not true if the “outer” universe is vastly bigger than ours, such that it’s feasible to genuinely simulate our entire universe in it.

          It’s worth remembering that this is functionally equivalent to saying “it’s feasible to run the Sims in our universe”. As far as the Sims are concerned, SimVerse is just what universes are like (and SimSimulationst may imagine that SimVerse is a fairly accurate representation of our own).

          Log in to Reply
          • Brassfjord says:
            May 18, 2020 at 5:38 am

            The assessment that he doesn’t need to worry about capacity, still stands. Because the simulators can easily change the settings, so that the quantum state isn’t simulated of every electron in the universe.

            The SimVerse won’t break your computer, since it operates within its boundaries and parameters.

          • Faza (TCM) says:
            May 18, 2020 at 6:21 am

            Yes. That’s not the point.

            The point is that SimVerse is qualitatively different from our own, to the point of not being a simulation in anything but name. It’s not even a Potemkin village.

            Now, it may be an interesting intellectual exercise to atempt mentally modelling a Sim as being “just like you and me” – and I could probably knock out a decent story or two just based on my playthroughs – but I hope nobody is considering this a serious ontological proposition.

            While it’s not necessarily impossible for there to exist a “higher-level” universe within which our own is simulated, one thing we can be sure of is that it is qualitatively different from our own just as much as SimVerse is. We, quite literally, cannot reason about it.*

            * If our own universe may exist in an arbitrarily large but finite number of states, the simulating universe must be capable of existing in a number of states equal to (number of states of the simulating universe aside from simulation * number of states in the simulated universe); otherwise the simulating universe would be incapable of simulating. Given that our reasoning about the simulating universe explores a subset of states available to our own (just assuming a simulating universe exists halves the number available), we do not have “state capacity” to even begin conceptualising what the simulating universe may be like.

          • Brassfjord says:
            May 18, 2020 at 7:04 am

            @ Faza

            one thing we can be sure of is that it is qualitatively different from our own just as much as SimVerse is. We, quite literally, cannot reason about it.

            It’s possible to simulate a universe that is the same as the simulating universe – in appearance. In ”essence” they differ, but that’s not anything the simulated beings can determine.

          • Faza (TCM) says:
            May 18, 2020 at 7:31 am

            It’s possible to simulate a universe that is the same as the simulating universe – in appearance.

            “In appearance” is doing a hell of a lot of work here.

            Ceci n’est pas une pipe.

            In ”essence” they differ, but that’s not anything the simulated beings can determine.

            How would you propose that simulated beings go about this determination, given that the simulating universe is fundamentally inaccessible to them?

            The simulating beings, on the other hand, can tell the difference at a glance.

          • John Schilling says:
            May 18, 2020 at 8:50 am

            A hypothetical Sentient Sim can look around and see that his universe is very coarsely granular in a way that suggests intelligent design for easy simulation, and that makes it unlikely any further simplification is possible without reducing the amount of Sim consciousness being simulated. That would give them a quantitatively different assessment of the probabilities and risks than a resident of our universe.

          • Brassfjord says:
            May 18, 2020 at 8:52 am

            @ Faza

            “In appearance” is doing a hell of a lot of work here.

            Yes, that was exactly the point. Anything else than appearance is only philosophy.

            The simulating beings, on the other hand, can tell the difference at a glance.

            Not necessarily. If they immerse themselves in the simulation via advanced VR, that universe could look exactly as their own.

          • 10240 says:
            May 18, 2020 at 11:37 am

            While it’s not necessarily impossible for there to exist a “higher-level” universe within which our own is simulated, one thing we can be sure of is that it is qualitatively different from our own just as much as SimVerse is.

            @Faza (TCM) Actually it could be just quantitatively different: e.g. having a much greater speed of light, sufficiently big to comfortably contain our universe, and with a few parameters changed such that a computer the size of our universe doesn’t collapse into a black hole. Equivalently, having elementary particles many orders of magnitude smaller compared to the scale of planets, allowing for much greater computational capacity.

            After all, we could run a physics simulation of a small portion of our universe (in a much more realistic way than simulation games do), it would just be many orders of magnitude smaller (in terms of, say, the number of particles contained) than our universe, most likely too small for intelligent life to develop. I see no reason an outer universe where some scales are much bigger couldn’t simulate ours in a similar way. (I’ve ignored that simulating quantum mechanics, as currently understood, takes exponential time in a conventional computer; I know very little about quantum mechanics. As far as I understand, assuming that the quantum mechanics of the outer universe is similar to ours, it would be feasible to simulate our universe using a sufficiently big quantum computer. Or else, perhaps, in a conventional computer they could simulate quantum interactions only between nearby particles; I don’t know if we could detect that.)

            I don’t follow your arguments that we can’t even conceptualize what the simulating universe may look like. Sure, we can’t describe a particular state of the outer universe, and we can’t know anything about it with certainty (except what it can’t look like, e.g. its information content can’t be too small), but that doesn’t prevent us from hypothesizing what its physical laws might be like.

    • noyann says:
      May 18, 2020 at 3:43 am

      I agree with @Kaitian that a professional should look at this.

      Meanwhile, consider the following: If you are part of a simulation, you are yourself simulated. Including all your decisions. So if someone/something is responsible for breaking the simulation, it is the programmer of that simulation, not you.

      Log in to Reply
    • Artischoke says:
      May 18, 2020 at 4:37 am

      You’re clearly lucid about the whole situation. You know its the OCD talking and that its not leading you towards an accurate or useful perspective on the world. Therefore I think engaging with your OCD in an object-level discussion about simulation hypotheses has yielded all the fruit it could possibly yield. You know what’s up. So what’s next? I think a useful direction is working on the OCD directly, through therapy or meditation etc. rather than engaging with the anxieties the OCD brings up and “arguing with your OCD”.

      Log in to Reply
    • James Miller says:
      May 18, 2020 at 5:27 am

      Scott had a post about a woman who kept worrying that a hair dryer would burn down her home, and the solution was for her to take the hair dryer with her. In that spirit, why not take action to reduce the complexity of the universe in a way that wouldn’t be damaging to yourself or others if the simulation hypothesis is false? Perhaps you could purchase a lot of used CDs and then erase the contents. Your actions could offset any complexity you naturally add to the simulation.

      Log in to Reply
      • Snickering Citadel says:
        May 18, 2020 at 7:14 am

        Buying and erasing CDs for that purpose is insane. I’m not a shrink, but to do crazy stuff like that seems like it would make a person more crazy.

        Log in to Reply
        • James Miller says:
          May 18, 2020 at 10:42 am

          Not doing it is insane if doing it would make you feel better. Sometimes when I’m trying to fall asleep I have an irrational fear that I have left the space heater in my office on and it will burn down my house while I sleep. I get up to check the heater because this makes it easier for me to fall asleep even though I know I carefully made sure the heater was off when I left my office.

          Log in to Reply
          • Snickering Citadel says:
            May 18, 2020 at 11:58 am

            Checking the heater is a lot less crazy than buying and deleting CDs.

          • Ghatanathoah says:
            May 18, 2020 at 5:23 pm

            James Miller

            In regards to the heater, I have a similar problem with locking the door at night. One thing that helps me is to take a photo of the lock on my phone. Then if I worry about it I can check my phone on the nightstand instead of having to get out of bed. When I leave my apartment I videotape myself locking the door.

            I have to delete a lot of pictures of locks, but it mostly helps. Could you do that with your heater?

          • James Miller says:
            May 18, 2020 at 6:46 pm

            Ghatanathoah,

            Thanks. I’ve put the heater away for the summer but next winter I will consider implementing your suggestion.

    • Deiseach says:
      May 18, 2020 at 6:17 am

      Either the world is real, or it is not.

      If it is not real, then why worry? So what if the simulators pull the plug? They could do it for a host of reasons besides you and your dog – they got bored, the funding ran out, they found out what they wanted, there’s a newer, shinier, cooler tech come along they want to try instead, they’ve practiced enough and now they’re ready to try real-time, real-world creation, and so on.

      If they turn it off, they could turn it back on any time. If they never turn it on again, who of us shadows and puppets will know or care? It will be death and it won’t matter if we all flicker out in the next minute. Do you worry about the characters in a book when you’ve finished reading and closed the volume? (Please don’t start worrying about imaginary characters).

      If the world is real, then you getting a dog is not going to trigger The End Of Days.

      Log in to Reply

        May 18, 2020 at 6:44 am

    • Taleuntum says:
      May 18, 2020 at 6:32 am

      Why did you think it will save us resources to simulate this many replies to your comment? Arghh..
      Anyway, we love your dog, we call it b̸̛̘͔͉̫̠͚̲̻̦̹̹̖̄̈͌̈́̓͘͜͜l̷̛͓̟̥̊̇̒̍̿́̊̑͋̈́̚͝ö̴̡͈̩̳͕̮̥̪̭̤͎̬͍̟́̿͑̄̑͋͂̇̒̇̆͘͘̚k̴̘̰̪̠͍͚̰͐̃̑͊͋̐̄́̂͘͜i̷͚̙͈̪̱̜͔̺̰̻̯͑̈́̆͛̈́͑̍̂̈ͅ (translates badly), so we will probably shut down your brain-simulation earlier than its.
      But if you want to help us concerning computation needs, there are a few things you can do:
      1. Don’t eat junk food in big franchises. It is very resource-intensive to simulate global supply chains, so we would prefer you getting your food from your local producers.
      2. Go for a run more often! We have to simulate large parts of your city anyway to produce convincing traffic/pedestrians, so we would appreciate if you saw more of it and not only the houses on your usual routes.
      Also sorry for the strange geopolitics/global events, we are aware of the bug and will fix it before the workday is up (in your time: a few million years).

      -Simulators

      Log in to Reply
      • CatCube says:
        May 18, 2020 at 7:20 am

        Don’t do this.

        Log in to Reply
      • Jakub Łopuszański says:
        May 18, 2020 at 1:29 pm

        Don’t boil goat in its mothers milk.

        Log in to Reply
    • Snickering Citadel says:
      May 18, 2020 at 7:57 am

      Say someone is raised Christian, then stops believing but still has a fear of hell. A fear they know is irrational. Something that maybe helps is to think, am I afraid of, for instance, Muslim hell or Norse mythology hell? And if the answer is no, then why be afraid of Christian hell? Only reason the person is afraid of that particular hell is the person happened to be raised Christian instead of Muslim or Norse mythology. So there is no need to be afraid.

      So maybe that technique can be applied to your situation. You can postulate a simulation that will stop working if you get a dog. But you can also postulate a simulation that stops working if you don’t get a dog. Like maybe it was supposed to be a simulation to see how you would raise dogs or whatever.

      It is impossible to tell the motives of whoever is running the simulations. So all the potential simulations cancel each other out. So there is no point in worrying about your actions ending a simulation.

      Log in to Reply
      • Ghatanathoah says:
        May 18, 2020 at 5:35 pm

        I will try that, thanks. A scientific or animal rights-obsessed simulator seems just a likely, if not more so, then a simulator that is smart enough to manage a simulation, but not smart enough to manage its budget.

        Log in to Reply
    • Jakub Łopuszański says:
      May 18, 2020 at 1:38 pm

      It looks to me like you are conflating levels of hierarchy in similar way as people who ask what was before big bang or what is outside the universe. If you turn off a game the characters in it do not execute the animation of dying – they just vanish. The end of simulation is nothing to fear as it is not something that can “happen” as to “happen” inside the simulation you need the simulation to be running.
      So there is nothing to worry about IMHO.
      Also a “hardware” powerful enough to run such sim probably can afford saving a snaphot – and I am imagining this quite abstractly as I have no idea what “hardware” really means outside our sim. It can be for example just some math equation/structure Wolfram’s style, or thought of some being or maybe even “The universe doesn’t run on math”. Such hardware can pause and unpause and perhaps rewind the sim or maybe it even makes no sense to use such verbs and time relations if you speak about the outside level – what makes sense to us is the notion of time as we perceive it inside, which afaiu has more to do woth causal links and structure of physics’ rules than with speed of hardware which simulates it, so it also shouldn’t matter if it stops. For that matter the whole Universe can be a one big 4D crystal (or something more complicated because of quantum mechanics) computed/rendered in cometely different order than the one we perceive.

      Log in to Reply

    Happy Faire of Short-Stories, everyone! It’s my favourite Peculiar Holiday and I very nearly missed it (I am told this one is the last on the calendar; we had a Faire last year as well; though as schlaugh makes it (deliberately) hard to link to a feed of several people’s stuff that you haven’t consciously chosen to follow, there’s no public-by-default link I could give you for the two dates that Faire-related posts went up on).

I won’t separately post the story up here once it’s published (it will go up with tomorrow’s schlaugh), because it’s not geared toward this audience, but I’m pleased I managed to hit the deadline despite my delayed attention! If you’re interested in it for some reason, you can just look out for my schlaugh tomorrow. 🙂

    a) Very interested in learning more
    b) Somewhat interested in learning more

      a)! I used to play RPGs years ago, and I also participated in some email games – which I thought were really great. Not that the story ever got anywhere – IME the written medium led to much better and more interesting role play, and a stronger focus on story and characters and less on mechanics.

      So I took a look at your links, but this seems to be not so much about roleplaying as an action/combat game? Or did I completely misunderstand this?

      Log in to Reply
      • Vermillion says:
        May 18, 2020 at 4:52 am

        Appreciate the interest! The previous game was indeed more of an action combat thing and I thought it went fine, but this would be different. In that there would be an actual story involved that we’d be co-telling.

        Aside from the main story beats I don’t have too much prepared and all these mechanical pieces are up for discussion. I didn’t think the usual pencil and paper systems would work very well and so I thought about doing something more homebrewed which is where the idea of adapting Rumble came from.

        The basic gameplay loop, after everyone picks out their powers would be 1) I send out a description of the scene, maybe you’re fighting giant robots, negotiating with demons, or trying to thwart your nemesis, The Hirsute Defender. 2) you reply with what you intend to do, and how you’re like to use your energy and powers to do it. 3) I tabulate all the results as I please then send out a digest to everyone and we’re back to 1, make sense?

        Log in to Reply

  53. toastengineer says:
    May 17, 2020 at 8:11 pm

    Re-re-re-posting my invitation to the Unofficial Slate Star Codex Extremely Heavily Modded Minecraft Server. I’ll be posting this again in the next two integer and half-integer OTs unless someone tells me to cut it out.

    We now have four players, counting myself, and we’re having a ton of fun. We’ve all moved to nuclear power, now, keeping our heat engines with a portal to Hell on the hot side as backup. Right now we get around via basically-free teleportation, but I’ve decided to remove that ability and set up rail infrastructure instead. For our space program, the vehicles are built, and my basement factory is ready to make spacesuits on-demand, The only hold up now is oil refining for fuel – I don’t like the idea of just teleporting the stuff from the derrick to the refinery, so rails may end up as a prerequisite.

    To play on the server:

    Short version: We’re running the Technic 1.12.2 pack; the address is unofficialsscmc.404.mn

    You will need to have purchased Minecraft, and have a Mojang account to log in with.
    1. Go to technicpack.net and hit “Get the Launcher.” Download and run the launcher.
    2. Type “The 1.12.2 Pack” in to the search bar. Hit “install” in the bottom right corner of the window.
    3. Wait.
    4. Hit “play,” it’ll be where the download button was.
    5. Wait.
    6. Go to “multiplayer,” then “Add Server.”
    7. Paste unofficialsscmc.404.mn in to the Server Address box. Put whatever you want in Server Name. Hit done.
    8. Double click the new entry at the bottom of the server list.
    9. It should just work from that point on. If you have a problem, tell me about it in this thread, or EMail me – my address is my username at gmail.

    The paid-for dedicated server is coming, uh, soonish.

    Log in to Reply
  54. edmundgennings says:
    May 17, 2020 at 7:54 pm

    One thing which alters my consumer behavior is how much me buying something benefits the seller. I care more about my well being than theirs, but I do care somewhat particularly if they are helping out the community. Thus, I am more inclined to buy non rivalrous good than rivalrous ones. If I buy a laptop, the producers have to make an additional laptop, but if I buy a digital Monster Manual, the marginal cost to the producers is zero. But the additional money might play some role in encouraging an additional entrant into the market or more complicated possibly negative effects such as spat book bloat. The latter seems mentally intractable, but is any one such as our resident law and econ scholar aware of evidence that a marginal increase in producer surplus is higher for non rivalrous goods?

    Log in to Reply
  55. AG says:
    May 17, 2020 at 7:41 pm

    So I could talk about the operas I quite enjoyed in these past 9 weeks, thanks to the Met streaming a different one every day (plus a bonus one meant for students each week). In fact, I’ve enjoyed most of them.

    Instead, let’s do hot takes. Here are the ones I was unable to finish!
    La Boheme: skipped twice. I’ve seen this before already, and I have a limited attention span for Puccini more often than not. Not interested in Sad Artists Falling In Love And Dying.
    Tristan and Isolde: I understand that the whole point of the thing was for it not to musically resolve until the end, but getting edged for over 4 hours straight ain’t my thing.
    Die Meistersinger: Comedies should be fast paced
    Tannhauser: I have the Venusberg excerpted in my music library already.
    Nixon in China: Actually, I watched like 90%, and just tapped out over halfway through that interminable last act (it pretty much peaked at “let’s show these motherfuckers how to dance”). If I want to learn about philosophy, I’ll read philosophy. Don’t need it in much slower paced song form.
    Don Carlo: I also have attention issues with Verdi sometimes, plus I made the mistake of reading about the real Don Carlo, and the hilarity of the contrast put me off of the opera.
    Aida: I did indeed rag on Wagner last time, but I will admit that his plotting and characterization alone is sometimes enough to keep me interested. I’m most likely to skip out on Verdi when the plots are just “love triangle causes everyone to suffer,” unless he paces the arias well.
    Parsifal: Speaking of pacing issues. Indeed, the characterization did seem somewhat interesting, another case of Opera Does Philosophy Very Slowly.
    Boris Godunov: I don’t remember any melodies from what I did watch. The Game of Thrones needs better pacing.
    Madame Butterfly: skipped twice. I am also not fond of “a man is just The Worst, which makes the heroine suffer and prolly die” plots, unless, like, there is an epic mad scene to make up for it.
    Elektra: Too much Suffering For Everyone (including my ears), and another Opera Does Philosophy Very Slowly case.
    La Cenerentola: Once you’ve seen the best of Rossini, you don’t need to see his less than best. (Also I had just seen Cendrillion, staged in a more interesting way, so.)
    Roberto Devereux: Donizetti Queen Fatigue, that’s all.
    Luisa Miller: Verdi fatigue strikes again!
    L’Amour de Loin: I need to be able to head bang when someone asks what is love.
    Capriccio: Everyone in this is insufferable.
    Werther: Sad boy is sad. Boring.

    Honorable mention goes to Il Trovatore, which I did finish just because I figured I should see it once, and it was the first week and the first Verdi. The Anvil Chorus was great, and Leonora’s aria in the 4th act was very good, but it would be an opera I skip if it aired a different week. Like, even one of the actors took potshots at it during intermission, joking about a restaurant in Italy that will offer a free bottle of wine to the person who can explain the plot of Il Trovatore, and no one has succeeded at the challenge yet.

    Log in to Reply

    • Ouroborobot says:
      May 17, 2020 at 11:50 pm

      Most of my opera consumption is audo-only, usually while working, and I find that helps my enjoyment of it. For me it’s mostly about the music, although I’m a sucker for a traditional Wagner staging. The number of of operas I actually enjoy sitting and watching in their entirety is probably around ten percent of the operas I enjoy listening to, and a large part of that is because so many librettos are dreck. One of my favorites is Rigoletto. I once made the mistake of describing the plot to my wife, and I think it may have put her off opera forever.

      Peter Grimes (my favorite opera of all time)
      Khovanschina
      Porgy and Bess

  56. Squirrel of Doom says:
    May 17, 2020 at 7:10 pm

    I’ve become interested in the “ingroup/outgroup” thing we humans do, as I think it explains a lot of political polarization and other things in a much better way than the standard models people have.

    But… I don’t actually know much about it! I’ve picked up bits and pieces in various readings, and I have a homegrown intuition for it, but I would really like to read a solid book about the science of it.

    So this is a request for recommendations of such a book!

    Log in to Reply
    • Jitters says:
      May 17, 2020 at 7:34 pm

      Have you read The Righteous Mind? That book and Jonathan Haidt’s work in general seem to be at the center of this discussion.

      There was another book called Moral Tribes by Joshua Greene, who worked or studied with Haidt in some way. It’s been criticized for Greene eventually coming to the conclusion that his own previously held morality and political positions were right all along.

      Log in to Reply
      • Wrong Species says:
        May 17, 2020 at 9:10 pm

        The criticisms of Greene are correct but he has good insights in his book. He’s one of the people trying to take ethics from its lofty heights and help us make some sense of it and its purpose.

        Log in to Reply
      • Squirrel of Doom says:
        May 18, 2020 at 9:46 am

        I’m looking for a “pure science” Sociology book (if that’s even the right branch of science). Haidt’s book seems more of a polemic.

        That said, everyone keeps recommending The Righteous Mind, so I just ordered it. Even if it doesn’t do much to answer my question, it seems like a Must Read book for our time.

        Thanks for pushing me to action 🙂

  58. DavidFriedman says:
    May 17, 2020 at 6:47 pm

    I am trying the experiment of hosting a weekly SSC online meetup, using Mozilla Hubs. Like the meetups I hosted in realspace, it will have no specified talk or topic, just casual socializing and conversation. The reason I am using Hubs instead of Zillow or one of its competitors is that it provides a VR environment, in which someone’s voice is louder the closer you are to him, which makes it possible to have multiple conversations going at once and to wander around looking for one that interests you. I may eventually switch to Town Meeting, which has a similar feature implemented in a different way, but since I’m familiar with Hubs I will start with that.

    The meeting is Saturday at noon Pacific Time, which should cover everyone from California through Europe. To join, click hub.link/q7PLxgT.

    Feel free to pass the invitation on to anyone you think would enjoy it.

    Log in to Reply
    • 10240 says:
      May 17, 2020 at 7:50 pm

      Link fixed. (Missing https:// .)

      Log in to Reply
  59. matthewravery says:
    May 17, 2020 at 6:27 pm

    COVID-19 response is a collective action problem.

    Consider a toy example where everyone in society has two choice: They can (1) go out and about as normal, or (2) only leave the house for absolute essentials and take maximal precautions (PPE, etc.) when out.

    (1) Maximizes the benefits of any individual. They don’t have to deal with PPE, don’t have to avoid places they like, etc. (2) carries with it a ton of inconveniences. However, with (2), an individual will also minimize their risks of getting C19. Each person can act rationally and choose the behavior that is optimal w.r.t. benefits and risks.

    However, an individuals’s choice isn’t the only thing that effects their risks. If everyone else chooses 2, then the risks from (1) are substantially diminished. And if someone chooses (1), it (marginally) increases the risk of everyone else getting C19. (People may be irresponsible and go out and about even though they have C19 or they may be an asympomatic carrier of the virus and not realize it. Doesn’t really matter.)

    Moreover, the more folks choose (1), the longer the virus persists in the community.* This means that your choice of (1) makes the other people will rationally choose (2) longer, imposing additional choices.

    This is a collective action problem. Costs associated with your choices are born by others. This leads you to make choices that are individually optimal but collectively suboptimal.**

    A C19-free community (people, stores, restaurants, etc.) is a public good. When our community has no (or minimal) risk of C19 transmission, everyone benefits from it. Anyone can enjoy this benefit by having a small-to-no chance of getting C19 when they go to the grocery store. My enjoyment of this boon doesn’t diminish your ability to also enjoy it. The decisions of any one individual don’t effect (except at the margins) how C19-free the community is, but the decisions of many individuals can.

    People who choose (1) in the first toy example are free-riding on the prosocial decisions of others. They are acting antisocially and selfishly. They are the ship captain who uses the lighthouse to keep his ship from the rocks but refuses to pay towards its maintenance and upkeep. They are the project team member whose contributes no work but gets the same project evaluation as their team members. They are the Wikipedia user who has clicked through 100,000 articles but has yet to contribute even $1.

    *Some folks will disagree and think every community should just do an NYC or Italy (except triple what they did because NYC is at ~20% infected now, not 60%) and then we’ll have herd immunity more quickly and be able to lift measures. I’m assuming that (in the US) our collective will doesn’t want that and that the best way to get distancing restrictions lifted is to get new case counts very low.

    **This toy examples ignores the folks who don’t have a choice between (1) and (2) but must be present in potentially dangerous settings (poorly-ventilated warehouses, packing plants, grocery stores, etc.) for their occupation. Other folks choosing (1) increases the risks these folks must face irrespective of their own choices.

    Log in to Reply
    • baconbits9 says:
      May 17, 2020 at 6:57 pm

      You are modeling this incorrectly. Your assumptions only hold if you your equilibrium is everyone wearing PPE and taking preventative measures for Covid before an outbreak begins. When that isn’t true and few or no people are taking preventative measures at the onset then you have the exact opposite conclusion- that protecting yourself is your best decision and the collective action problem goes away.

      Secondly you are modeling this as if everyone has exactly average costs, when you shift that to large differences in outcomes for easily self identifiable groups then the calculation completely changes and those people should aggressively protect themselves.

      Moreover, the more folks choose (1), the longer the virus persists in the community

      There is no evidence or reason to expect this to be true, if the entire population protected themselves perfectly and then one person stopped there would almost certainly be no additional time of infections, and likewise the difference between 1 person protecting themselves and zero would also have no additional time of infections. As such it is almost certainly a curve and not a linear relationship between personal protections taken and total time of infections.

      Long story short your conclusions are assumption and not fact driven.

      Log in to Reply
      • gbear605 says:
        May 17, 2020 at 8:51 pm

        >> Moreover, the more folks choose (1), the longer the virus persists in the community

        > There is no evidence or reason to expect this to be true, if the entire population protected themselves perfectly and then one person stopped there would almost certainly be no additional time of infections, and likewise the difference between 1 person protecting themselves and zero would also have no additional time of infections. As such it is almost certainly a curve and not a linear relationship between personal protections taken and total time of infections.

        While the marginal behavior at the perfect point is zero, the marginal behavior at the current point is equal to the R0*your chance of being infected (per my understanding, which is admittedly limited). I agree that it’s definitely a curve and not linear, but that doesn’t mean that the assumption is wrong.

        Log in to Reply
        • baconbits9 says:
          May 18, 2020 at 6:23 am

          No, it means your assumption is unsupported as there are clear points where an change in PPE does not decrease the length of time the virus is in the population.

          However your assumption is wrong, if use of PPE drops the R value then with a basic model there are substantial stretches where increasing PPE causes the length of time in the population to rise. This was the logic behind ‘flatten the curve’ where you get a similar number of total infections but spread out over a longer time horizon.

          Log in to Reply

    • kaathewise says:

      Well, of course you are right. That’s also why it’s a classical example of a collective action problem that we need the government for. Nothing even remotely close to the lockdown wouldn’t have happened if not announced from above.

      Log in to Reply
    • LesHapablap says:
      May 17, 2020 at 10:54 pm

      A C-19 free community is a public good. It is a public good that is so expensive, that if the actual cost was a) blatantly obvious and/or b) not spread around but only charged to those that benefited, nobody would decide it was a good idea to buy it. But because the government can coordinate and mandate the purchase, and the price is difficult to see, we are all stuck buying something that almost nobody wants*.

      *would you spend $10,000,000 to save your 80 year old grandparent? Even if you could get great interest rates like your government can? How many grandparents would ask their children to do that?

      How many Americans would give to a charity that saved almost exclusively elderly with medical conditions, at a cost of $10,000,000 each? Especially when there are charities out there that can save younger people for $2,000, which very few Americans donate to?

      The fact is that people value quality of life over quantity, whether it is quantity of African children’s lives or quantity of their own life. We eat delicious food and drink alcohol and ride motorbikes and drive cars. That is the revealed preference and it makes perfect sense until we are driven to panic by something scary like a new virus.

      Log in to Reply

          Les is a Kiwi, and I believe has forecast that New Zealand’s economy is going to crater and hard if they follow through with their current plans.

          Log in to Reply
          • Matt M says:
            May 18, 2020 at 8:52 am

            Right. NZ has “decided to buy it” sure, but not only has the bill not arrived yet, they don’t even know what the final bill is actually going to be…

            Individuals and governments both have long and storied histories of buying things that in hindsight, they ought not to have…

          • Edward Scizorhands says:
            May 18, 2020 at 9:39 am

            Sweden has also made a decision to “buy it.” They just bought something else.

            You can’t optimize for “deciding not to buy anything.” All available options suck.

          • Matt M says:
            May 18, 2020 at 10:10 am

            Well, the difference is that NZ is buying a service where you get the majority of the benefit right now, and pay the majority of the costs later.

            Sweden is buying a thing where you pay the cost now, and derive the benefit later.

            One of those roughly maps to going in debt, the other roughly maps to making an investment.

          • albatross11 says:
            May 18, 2020 at 12:26 pm

            NZ is in a pretty special position, since it’s so far away from most of the rest of the world. They make money on tourism, but tourists from places other than Australia already have a loooong trip to get there, so probably they can add a bit of overhead to the trip and still keep a substantial amount of tourism.

            More generally, I think most international borders are already set up to restrict who can come in and make visitors jump through some hoops, and it won’t be so hard to add in a few COVID-related ones that keep imported cases under control. For example, in order to come into our country, you have to get a certified test a week before entry, and take another one as you enter the country. (Either they develop a rapid test or they make you wait in some well-ventilated, socially-distanced place until you get the results.) That plus a basic symptom check at the border probably catches the great majority of cases before they enter the country.

          • Mycale says:
            May 18, 2020 at 1:26 pm

            @albatross11,
            My understanding of quarantine procedures implemented by countries trying to wipe out COVID-19 is that they are generally set to require 14 days of isolation. My quick Google search re: NZ’s policy seems to align with that (they implemented a 14 day quarantine for NZ citizens or permanent residents who had traveled in China back when this was still ramping up; I don’t know exactly what their current policy is).

            There is an enormous difference between traveling to New Zealand costing you 20-30 hours of flight time versus it costing you 20-30 hours of flight time plus 14 days of quarantine upon arrival. If you were planning a three week vacation (which is already quite long! At least speaking as an American), then the quarantine would consume two-thirds of your vacation time. I’ve heard that NZ is great, but I don’t think it’s that great.

            I would be surprised if countries implementing a 14-day isolation requirement for all tourists saw less than a 99% decrease in international tourism. As someone who had been planning to travel internationally later in 2020 before all this happened, and who is now trying to figure out what my new travel plans will be once things open back up, I can confidently say that I’m not going to go anywhere with a quarantine period that is measured in days. I expect a massive supermajority of tourists will feel the same way.

            Edited to add, I think there’s no compromise position on the quarantine period either. My understanding is that any quarantine shorter than at minimum five days would be of little use in preventing the reintroduction of COVID-19 to an area, such as by asymptomatic carriers. Therefore, even a quarantine of 2-3 days would be useless public health security theater while simultaneously being massively obnoxious to any tourists. I think any quarantine long enough to be useful will wipe out tourism.

          • LesHapablap says:
            May 18, 2020 at 2:37 pm

            The new budget just came out in NZ, so we have an idea what the government’s economic recovery plan is going to be, and it is forecast to add 140 billion in debt by 2024 link text

            That’s $28,000 per person in NZ, or 1.9MM per COVID-19 life saved under the worst projections (70% infected, 1% IFR). And the economy is forecast to shrink anyway, with -4.6% GDP this year and 1% GDP next year: link text

            Then there are the human costs that are not included in those figures. Migrants here forced to leave. Kiwis abroad forced to come back. People having to move within the country to find new jobs. Relationships broken apart. People not allowed to attend funerals and postponing weddings. Single people living alone suffering isolation. Unemployment, raising the retirement age, millions of tourists who would have had great experiences here who now can’t. Mortgage foreclosures, bankruptcies and legal fights. Erosion of government trust and the rise of weird conspiracy theories (there have been several cell phone towers burned down in the last week by 5G conspiracy nuts). Increased susceptibility to future disasters. Lowered life expectancy. Increased stress.

          • LesHapablap says:
            May 18, 2020 at 2:42 pm

            @albatross11,

            Iceland is opening its borders on June 15th with COVID testing on arrival, and if you test positive you’re in quarantine. There’s no reason that couldn’t be done in NZ that I’m aware of. Currently though all arrivals have a 14-day quarantine. There is enormous and growing pressure to get things opened up again here though.

            If 2% of visitors are happy with a reduced quarantine, it still leaves the problem that no airline can run a scheduled flight on that kind of volume. So unless they are chartering a plane they aren’t coming here.

          • albatross11 says:
            May 18, 2020 at 3:19 pm

            I think how effective this is depends a lot on:

            a. The false negative rate of the test

            b. The period between when you’re exposed and when you *can* test positive.

            c. What fraction of people catch C19 while traveling.

            If we assume 10% false negative rate and 90% of exposed and will-be-contagious people are currently making enough virus to test positive, then an RNA test as you enter catches 81% of people who are going to be contagious.

            Doing better requires serial testing in hopes that your false negatives don’t repeat, and adding a short quarantine in hopes that you’re past the time between exposure and having enough virus to be able to test positive.

            I think you’d also want to test on exit, to give your contact tracers a head start on catching any new cases.

          • Edward Scizorhands says:
            May 18, 2020 at 4:31 pm

            Testing everyone on the plane before it takes off helps with cases of it spreading from one person to another. Also, make sure you have some alternate form of tourism available for people who fail the tests.

            The Alex Tarrabok plan cals for America to be in red, yellow, and green zones. Green zones have 1-in-36,000 prevalence. New Zealand normally gets 1.2 million visitors a year. Let’s call it a million with some reduced travel. If you are coming from a green zone, that means there are 28 new cases per year. If you catch 81% of them, like albatross11 suggests, that means you only have to do the contact-trace-chase on less than a half person each month. (You could do a follow-up test X days after the person arrives and does tourist stuff, as long as you can shut up the people who demand all-or-nothing.)

            Now, obviously there aren’t going to be many green zones in the next few weeks. A yellow zone might have 0.1% of people having the virus. That means you want to catch 1000 people a year or 83 each month. If you are 81% successful at finding cases, that means you have 16 cases slip past you each month.

            This is a solvable problem if people want it to be solved. People can insist it’s unsolvable if they want that instead and you can’t change their minds.

          • LesHapablap says:
            May 18, 2020 at 5:05 pm

            Edward Scizzorhands,

            There’s a few problems with that:
            For one, the US is not going to have green zones with strict internal borders. They probably won’t end up with green zones at all as keeping the restrictions in place to get and keep infections that low won’t be politically possible.

            Even if the US claimed that they had strict internal borders and ‘guaranteed’ green zones, the NZ government is not going to just take that on faith. How are they going to verify that a US citizen hasn’t been in a yellow zone recently?

            Opening up to yellow zones and the 16 cases a month slipping by would mean rapid spread of infection in NZ and lead to us going back under lockdown. Tourists are super-spreaders: they travel the whole country dining in restaurants constantly, using public transport and taking group tours.

            Also NZ gets 2MM international tourists per year not 1.2MM.

            But I am hopeful that testing such as what Iceland is going to do (I don’t know the details of their test) will catch much more than 81% of positive cases. There’s other scenarios as well that let NZ open up the borders, such as good treatments coming out, a vaccine, more antibody data showing that the disease is not that fatal or that herd immunity is easier to reach. I am predicting around 35% chance that we have basically open borders again by December 2020.

            Tourism industry forecasts I have seen have said that under the optimistic scenario we won’t be opening our borders to the US and all other countries until Q3-2021, which I think is absurdly pessimistic. Their optimistic scenario has Australia in October 2020, China, Japan and South Korea Q1 2021, Germany and Singapore Q2 2021, and US, UK, India and all others in Q3 2021.

        • Jaskologist says:
          May 18, 2020 at 9:22 am

          I suspect they have some climate and especially geographical advantages that dominate the other factors.

          Log in to Reply
    • Christophe Biocca says:
      May 18, 2020 at 5:06 am

      Treating the decision making as binary eliminates a lot of the decision making here:

      don’t have a choice between (1) and (2) but must be present in potentially dangerous settings (poorly-ventilated warehouses, packing plants, grocery stores, etc.) for their occupation.

      There’s still the decision of continuing to work in their occupations or not. I’m not saying this to be callous, it’s a choice that people have actually made (my local grocery store had to give their workers raises, and there’s been substantial turnover in who’s working there as cashiers).

      As baconbits9 points out, this isn’t a public good, in the sense that there’s still private benefits to choosing 2) by yourself. It’s just that there’s additional benefit to others, which isn’t priced into individual decisionmaking. This is pretty much the textbook example of an externality (with the caveat that the set of beneficiaries isn’t everyone in society, but the specific people you might transmit the disease to). The current set of recommended/mandated behaviors are just an approximation for the theoretically-better-but-practically-intractable solution of transfer payments based on relative risk of transmitting the infection for each possible transmission between two people.

      Log in to Reply
      • albatross11 says:
        May 18, 2020 at 7:38 am

        Yeah, people stuck in prison while COVID-19 ravages the prison actually don’t have any choice about being there. The prison guards do have a choice, just a not-great choice of quitting their job during a period of the highest unemployment since the great depression or continuing to be exposed to lots of COVID-19. I expect some prison guards have quit to avoid catching the virus, but probably not many. (Being a prison guard isn’t all that safe or pleasant a job anyway, and few prison guards have a lot of other available options.)

        Something similar happens w.r.t. nursing homes and hospitals full of COVID-19 patients. And to a lesser extent with grocery stores and such.

        Log in to Reply

    • littskad says:
      May 18, 2020 at 4:11 pm

      Why would this same argument not apply to seasonal flu? Why should one believe that it is possible, let alone reasonable, to try to achieve a “C19-free community”, particularly by the methods you are advocating? The elimination or near-elimination of the diseases that we have been able to do (smallpox, measles, polio, malaria (in some regions), yellow fever (ditto), etc.) were achieved in completely different ways. Why should the methods you are advocating not be seen as mere tilting at windmills?

      Log in to Reply
      • Edward Scizorhands says:
        May 18, 2020 at 4:36 pm

        Without advocating for or against that particular plan, if coronavirus flu had a death rate of 3% for young heathy people, we would absolutely do what we can to eliminate it.

        We’ve decided to live with flu because its death rate is low enough. If you want to argue that we should revisit that calculus, go for it.

        Log in to Reply
        • littskad says:
          May 18, 2020 at 5:18 pm

          We are doing what we reasonably can to control flu—elimination is not a realistic goal at the moment. We can live with C19 in the same way, mostly because we have no choice about it. C19 is here, and there is no reason to believe that it is possible to eliminate it, either.

          If the argument someone is making is leading that they recommend a response orders of magnitude larger than the response to seasonal flu, it is reasonable to ask in what way their argument does not apply to seasonal flu, since there are not orders of magnitude in difference between the seriousness of C19 and seasonal flu.

          Log in to Reply
          • albatross11 says:
            May 18, 2020 at 7:47 pm

            Seasonal flu has a bunch of animal reservoirs (including pigs and several species of birds, both wild and domesticated), so it’s probably very hard to get rid of even if we could vaccinate all the humans. Covid-19 probably doesn’t have any animal reservoirs likely to reinfect us once the wet markets in Wuhan get shut down.

          • littskad says:
            May 18, 2020 at 8:13 pm

            Covid-19 has been verified to be able to infect at least cats and dogs. Even some lions and tigers in the Bronx zoo tested positive.

  60. Ninety-Three says:
    May 17, 2020 at 6:23 pm

    A while ago I asked here why the price of gasoline fluctuates so wildly when most other commodities don’t. I got the satisfying-seeming answer that gas is the rare commodity whose price is determined mostly by one raw ingredient rather than a complicated mix (like electronics) or production and shipping (like bread), so gas prices are tracking oil futures, which fluctuate for normal market reasons.

    I have since realized a problem with that explanation: Production-wise, diesel is basically identical to gasoline. They come from the same refineries and sell in the same stations, yet diesel has a noticeably more stable price. So what market force is causing diesel and gas pricing to behave differently?

    Log in to Reply
    • Jon S says:
      May 17, 2020 at 6:30 pm

      I don’t know about the diesel difference, but I’d suggest that a lot of the volatility in oil prices is because it’s expensive for producers to start or stop production in the short term. So when there’s a sudden change in demand, it takes a while for supply to adjust. Storage alleviates this somewhat, but storing oil is expensive relative to the price of oil. I suppose this is really all just normal market reasons, but I think more relevant for oil than some other commodities and most finished goods.

      Log in to Reply
    • edmundgennings says:
      May 17, 2020 at 7:37 pm

      In addition to what you mentioned, with gasoline you have highly inelastic (short run)supply, highly highly inelastic(short run) demand, linked to that limited substitutes, and limited capacity for storage relative to the amount consumed. This is a recipe for volatile prices.
      If tomorrow bread cost 80% more, I would buy less bread. My driving behavior would not be altered if gas cost 80% more. I drive when and where I “need” to and otherwise I do not drive.
      Also because driving is thought of as a need, some percentage of the population has a decent amount of their gas bills paid for by their company etc. The effect is not huge, but it does make gas consumption even less elastic.

      Log in to Reply
      • cassander says:
        May 17, 2020 at 8:45 pm

        gasoline is also more perishable than diesel.

        Log in to Reply
    • Konstantin says:
      May 17, 2020 at 8:01 pm

      America plays on gas and works on diesel. Most gas is used in passenger cars owned by individuals, most diesel is used in heavy trucks and machinery owned by businesses. People’s driving habits can change quickly, while businesses generally don’t like to have their trucks sitting idle.

      Log in to Reply
      • LesHapablap says:
        May 17, 2020 at 10:56 pm

        Also could be that airlines hedge fuel prices so much that the price is stabilized, right? Jet A is very similar to diesel as a fuel.

My sense that they all change in lock step is because the off road diesel is always just a fraction more than half the price of 98 gasoline.
