    • MVDZ says:
      May 18, 2020 at 2:52 am

      >America plays on gas and works on diesel. Most gas is used in passenger cars owned by individuals, most diesel is used in heavy trucks and machinery owned by businesses. People’s driving habits can change quickly, while businesses generally don’t like to have their trucks sitting idle.

      This. Construction, transportation, mining, agriculture: the world runs on diesel. You can’t turn those industries off without the entire edifice of complex society collapsing.

      Incidentally this is one of the biggest problems with the energy transition: finding a replacement fuel for heavy duty vehicles. The fact that even gasoline is incredibly inefficient of even impossible as a heavy duty fuel, despite being pretty close in energy density, should tell you quite a bit.
      There’s an interesting little book called ‘When trucks stop running’ by Alice Friedman (2013), a former logistics chain engineer who delved into alternatives for diesel-powered trucks and cargo trains (shipping is also turning to diesel more and more). Turns out it’s really hard to make batteries that don’t take up 90% of curb weight, or make electric engines based on fuel cells that can actually make a truck go uphill.
      There’s also a more recent study that compared Switzerland and Finland as cases. As far as I remember, Switzrland was viable despite being mountainous because most trips are short, so you could switch to medium-duty trucks that run shorter distances (up to 300km or something) with decent efficiency. Longer haul trips in a large country like Finland would not be viable in a battery future, however.

      Does anyone here have an interest in battery development and other diesel alternatives and if so, help me become less anxious about facing a negative post-industrial future?

      Log in to Reply
      • LesHapablap says:
        May 18, 2020 at 3:21 am

        Just recently there have been some electric mining trucks developed that could recharge on downhills, meaning that if they get loaded at the top and drop off at the bottom, they can run forever with no fuel or charging. Very limited use case since most mines won’t be able to set up that way, but saves a lot of fuel when it works.

        Log in to Reply
        • LesHapablap says:
          May 19, 2020 at 6:08 pm

          https://www.autoblog.com/2019/08/26/edumper-electric-mining-truck-self-charging/

          Log in to Reply
          • Austin says:
            May 20, 2020 at 8:00 am

            There is another technology that uses electric trolley assist to reduce diesel usage, which reduces costs as electric power is generally cheaper and more efficient.

            It also allows for uphill loaded hauls, which can occur later in a mine’s life as all the good downhill waste dumps get filled up, or as the mining areas drop below the plant elevation.

            The paper that I looked at discussed having two separate systems, one to power the uphill haul, and another to capture the braking energy on the downhill. Depending on the topography, this could be coupled with pumped hydro as the energy storage method, rather than having battery packs on every truck. Or depending on the scale of the pits, a much smaller battery pack for bench entrance -> shovel -> bench exit only.

      • AlphaGamma says:
        May 18, 2020 at 3:59 am

        There’s also a more recent study that compared Switzerland and Finland as cases. As far as I remember, Switzrland was viable despite being mountainous because most trips are short, so you could switch to medium-duty trucks that run shorter distances (up to 300km or something) with decent efficiency.

        AFAIK (and what I’ve seen on trips there) Switzerland has made a great deal of effort to shift as much freight as possible onto the railways. This may be part of why so many of the trips are short and suitable for electric trucks- most of the transport through mountains is done by trains. According to Eurostat, rail has a modal share of about 35% of inland freight transport in Switzerland. This is higher than anywhere except the Baltics (apparently the vast majority of rail freight traffic in the Baltics is transshipment of Russian coal, oil and gas to Baltic ports for export).

        Finland’s rail modal share seems to be similar, but I wonder if its railway network doesn’t cover as much of the country as the Swiss one does.

        (The Eurostat document is also interesting to see which countries make appreciable use of their inland waterways for freight- essentially Belgium, the Netherlands, and countries on the lower Danube…)

        Log in to Reply
      • Jake R says:
        May 18, 2020 at 8:26 am

        There’s always bio-diesel. My understanding is that right now bio-diesel takes more energy to produce than we can get out of it, but then that’s also true of batteries. If other sources of energy become cheap enough, then the efficiency loss of converting fission to bio-diesel can still be worth the higher energy density. I’m not an expert on this stuff though so take this with a grain of salt.

        Log in to Reply
      • DavidFriedman says:
        May 18, 2020 at 1:28 pm

        a negative post-industrial future

        Are you assuming we are going to run out of petroleum or ban it?

        Log in to Reply
    • Ninety-Three says:
      May 18, 2020 at 4:33 am

      Responses are highlighting that diesel and gas are used in different classes of vehicles, which is probably the origin of the difference, but “diesel and gas go in different trucks” is not an explanation of why one price is more swingy than the other. Are regular people more tolerant of swingy prices than the shipping industry which favours stations with more consistent diesel prices? Is it that the shipping industry would respond to swingy diesel prices by simply stockpiling diesel when it’s at its lowest point (since they have more incentive and ability to do so than people driving to work)? Is it because the shipping industry’s demand for diesel is less elastic than the consumer’s demand for gas so something something animal spirits, the price of diesel stabilizes?

      Log in to Reply
      • MVDZ says:
        May 18, 2020 at 5:15 am

        I think regular people can often just not afford it, or decide to prioritize other spending. This might be a big difference between Europe and the US. Not only is gas heavily taxed here (usually over half the total consumer price is tax) so it’s several times more expensive, it’s also often not quite necessary to drive. Sure, you have people like contractors, plumbers, builders and (for a stretched definition of necessary) sales reps making necessary trips, but otherwise you can almost always go to work by safe, clean and fast public transport. It’s *exceedingly* rare to find yourself away from your local or even regional economic hub my more than an hour. So while lots of people like having the privacy and flexibility of a car, it’s not like in the US where you often have to have a car just to go to work.

        Having said that, I don’t find a very major difference in the price decline of gas and diesel in the Netherlands, at least for retail. Perhaps they’re simply indexed to each other, or perhaps the diesel based economy is as hard hit as the gas one. Perhaps my reasoning is just wrong.

        Log in to Reply
      • Jon S says:
        May 18, 2020 at 6:37 am

        Yea, some of the other responses that suggest that diesel has inelastic demand would lead me to expect diesel to be more volatile than gas, not less.

        Log in to Reply
        • John Schilling says:
          May 18, 2020 at 8:47 am

          Why? The supply of diesel is also inelastic. The world’s ability to make diesel fuel, or gasoline or any other petrochemical commodity, hasn’t changed much and isn’t likely to change much. It’s been deemed an essential industry, so it’s still running, and if e.g. Saudi Arabia decides to either increase or decrease production for political reasons then marginal fields in North Dakota will be taken out of or put back into production accordingly.

          Inelastic supply of diesel plus inelastic demand for diesel = constant price for diesel. Inelastic supply of gasoline plus highly elastic demand for gasoline = volatile prices for gasoline.

          Log in to Reply
          • David W says:
            May 18, 2020 at 10:08 am

            No, that’s backward. Inelastic = very little change in amount bought/produced when price changes. Hence to cause a slight change in amount, you need to change the price by a lot.

            Toy example: You run a refinery, producing 1000 gal/day. You want to sell 1000 gal/day at the market price, which turns out to be $2.50/gal. Tomorrow you have a maintenance issue and produce 950 gal/day. To clear the market, you need to raise the price until you find someone who would have bought 50 gallons decides not to buy any.

            If it’s gasoline, bumping up the price by a little bit may be enough to make someone cancel their vacation plans. If it’s diesel, you’ve got to bump up the price enough to make someone put their construction site on hold or cancel a delivery, presumed to be a much bigger change in price.

            Maybe it’s something simpler. Diesel appears to be slightly more expensive and slightly stabler – maybe it’s sometimes sold in longer term contracts rather than spot price, and those contracts put the volatility risk on the seller, which is compensated by a higher average price.

          • Christophe Biocca says:
            May 18, 2020 at 10:14 am

            You’re using elasticity as a synonym for “variable over time” whereas others in the same discussion are using it to mean “responsiveness to price changes”. “Variability over time” would increase price swings, but “responsiveness to price changes” would decrease them.

          • baconbits9 says:
            May 19, 2020 at 5:22 am

            If it’s diesel, you’ve got to bump up the price enough to make someone put their construction site on hold or cancel a delivery, presumed to be a much bigger change in price.

            You have to model it both directions though. If you have to raise the price very high to push a construction project to halt then you will have to drop the price much lower when you get back to full capacity to induce them to restart. This would make large price shifts far less appealing and buffering solutions (like storage) far more appealing.

    • Christophe Biocca says:
      May 18, 2020 at 5:44 am

      I don’t have a good answer, but the energy information administration has pretty decent data sets for testing whatever theories get proposed.

      A quick look at weekly retail prices says the basic belief that there is more short term variance is correct.

      Log in to Reply
      • MVDZ says:
        May 18, 2020 at 6:17 am

        Yes, from what I see there’s a slightly quicker drop in gasoline, and it ends up being slightly bigger percentually. But not very significant.

        Log in to Reply

    There’s been a lot of “LOL who likes cruises?” stuff from media folks on Twitter. Having been on one, I just thought it was pretty cool being in luxury conditions on a boat way out to sea – being at sea itself was kind of cool.

    Log in to Reply
    • Erusian says:
      May 17, 2020 at 6:56 pm

      Growing up I never went on cruises and I didn’t know anyone who did either, despite coming from an affluent enough background basically all my friends’ families could have afforded to go. It simply wasn’t part of my world. I suspect this is still true for a lot of the Twitterati, which makes it easy to mock for basically classist reasons. (And there is a huge amount of classism and snobbery among people who otherwise pride themselves on their tolerance.)

      I was introduced to them by a girlfriend who was brilliant but from a family that wasn’t as well off. Going on cruises was high status in her community, so they went on cruises when they could afford a vacation. I went a couple of times with her. They were fun but they seemed geared at people with different cultural markers than me. I had a good time but it felt… I guess I would compare it to when I lived in England and used to go to pubs regularly. It isn’t that it wasn’t fun, or that it was incomprehensible why people did it, and it wasn’t that I wasn’t welcomed. I had fun, I understood, and I was welcomed. But it had a foreign tinge to it, for lack of a better term. After we broke up I haven’t been back, although I definitely felt I got my money’s worth and consider them good vacations. (There were several things like this: we had very different ideas of leisure and vacationing. Another was casinos.)

      One relevant thing might be that there are a lot of different cruise experiences. My only cruise was with my parents for their 25th anniversary years ago.       Log in to Reply
    • Gossage Vardebedian says:
      May 18, 2020 at 8:42 am

      Anti-cruise snobbery is a sine qua non of elite signaling. The point ostensibly being, you’re only in each city for one day and have no time to really learn about it. The Rick Steves and Tony Bourdain types of the world pooh-pooh cruising for the same reason – traveling vs tourism – and they have a point. But as the wise man says, everything is a tradeoff.

      We started cruising because our little kids thought it was exciting, and the kids’ clubs were great. We tried to choose cruises that would let us see things that would have been harder to do by land or air – Greek Isles, SE Asia, the Baltic states. Then go back to the places we liked later. I’ve been back to Stockholm, still want to go back to Helsinki and Oslo and see more of Scandinavia in general, but don’t need to see Copenhagen and St. Pete again. Been back to Barcelona, love Malaga, don’t need to see Valencia or Cartagena again. Etc.

      Now, we have also done a few Caribbean cruises, which I find kind of silly, because there isn’t much to do at most places other than go to the same horrible jewelry or trinket shops, or sit on one more beach, but people like to shop and sit on beaches, and it can be cheaper and a little more interesting than spending an entire week at resort X, and who am I to decide what people should do.

      Now that our kids are older we are starting to plan to mix in some overland trips with more time spent in certain places, but then again, a lot of cruises begin and end in rather interesting places, so a few days in Rome, then a cruise, then a few days in Athens, for example, sounds like a nice two weeks.

      Log in to Reply

      I’ve heard that people who need assisted living facilities sometimes go on a permanent cruise – because it is way more fun than the assisted living facility, and cheaper, too.

      In a cruise, you get laundry, cleaning, cooking, and round-the-clock entertainment, plus the company. If you don’t need a nurse, it can be quite a good option. And relatively affordable, too (from what I’ve heard, something like 60,000$/year).

  62. nkurz says:
    May 17, 2020 at 5:48 pm

    I’ve been looking for quantitive estimates of the infectiousness of COVID-19 for some standard interactions. For example, if an infected but asymptomatic person were to spend 30 seconds talking conversationally to an susceptible individual at a distance of 3 feet, what is the likelihood that the susceptible one will contract the disease? Same but situation, but longer times: 1 minute, 5 minutes, 10 minutes, 30 minutes — is infection risk linear with exposure? Same situation, but the infected individual is properly wearing an N95 mask. Same situation, but the uninfected individual is wearing a similar mask. Or both are wearing masks.

    I’d think these would be useful numbers to know, but I haven’t found anything concrete. What I have found seems to either be seemingly trustworthyl information about relative risk for healthcare workers for different activities (https://www.medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2020.03.27.20045336v1.full.pdf) or not particularly trustworthy general advice for the public (https://www.erinbromage.com/post/the-risks-know-them-avoid-them). Lacking are hard numbers, even though these numbers seem like they would be very useful to know. Do these numbers exist somewhere that I haven’t found?

    On my own, if we were to assume linearity with exposure time and that all transmission was spread by airborne droplets, it seems like one could come up with a rough estimate by looking at R0 and estimating the amount of contact time the infected individual has uninfected individuals during the time they are contagious but asymptomatic. But I don’t really even have a good guess at what this contact time might be, or whether the assumptions are reasonable. Are there better ways to at least establish bounds?

    Log in to Reply
    • albatross11 says:
      May 18, 2020 at 7:04 am

      nkurtz:

      It seems really hard to get those numbers, short of running experiments with people and COVID-19. The best we’ve got now seems to be contact tracing reports, but those don’t include a denominator.

  64. Iago the Yerfdog says:
    May 17, 2020 at 5:20 pm

    What are the economics of byproducts for which there is a very limited demand, such that the total amount desired is less than the amount produced as part of some other economic activity?

    What inspires this question is that a few years ago I was at a Captain D’s and a guy came in, asked for “cracklins” (the pieces of fried breading that flake off of the fish while cooking — not sure what they’re actually called) and was willing to pay, but they gave him a small box for free. These “cracklins” are produced as a byproduct of making fish, and would presumably just be thrown away normally.

    Ignoring the cost of the time for the employee to collect and box up the cracklins, and the cost of the box (realistically nonzero but very small), I’d expect that the supply curve would start out flat at zero, continuing this way until the point at which you’d have to start making cracklins intentionally. If the demand curve intersects the supply curve on this zero portion, the clearing price should be zero, which matches my observation that the guy was given it for free.

    Nevertheless, it seems like in this case your incentive as a producer is not to reach the clearing price, but to charge something. Some subset of the “cracklins”-demanding population are willing to pay, including the guy I saw actually order them. Since getting some money is better than getting none, it seems like the actual price should be above zero, despite the above argument.

    Which argument is more correct?

    Log in to Reply
    • Loriot says:
      May 17, 2020 at 5:23 pm

      Since getting some money is better than getting none

      Note that this isn’t necessary true for small amounts of money.

      Log in to Reply
      • Iago the Yerfdog says:
        May 17, 2020 at 5:26 pm

        That’s along the lines of what I’m thinking: charging for them at a price he would realistically pay would cost more than just giving them to him. For one thing, it holds up other, higher-paying customers.

        Log in to Reply
      • baconbits9 says:
        May 19, 2020 at 5:25 am

        It is also not true if disposal costs money.

        Log in to Reply
    • Erusian says:
      May 17, 2020 at 5:35 pm

      The way most businesses approach this is not to maximize the individual revenue of everything they supply but to maximize overall revenue of the business. For example, free bread rolls cost money and are purely an expense but are felt (probably with evidence) to increase the number of people making other purchases and thus to increase revenue more than their cost, even if they don’t directly create revenue.

      Thus the goal of a business is not to maximize revenue for each individual item but to maximize overall revenue, which is usually a matter of extracting cash at set points in the business model in exchange for specific, highly measurable goods or services.

      Therefore, when someone comes up and asks for cracklins the question is not how much they could charge for cracklins. It’s what they can do that will maximize the overall revenue of the business. One option would be to charge for cracklins but the question then is whether the revenue will outweigh the expense of supplying cracklins, especially with fixed costs of doing it regularly. On the other hand, giving away the cracklins for free (like the breadrolls) earns some good will for little to no cost and probably stimulates spending at the points where they’re designed to extract cash.

      If demand for cracklins increases to the point where the fixed costs of a cracklin supply chain become viable, then it can be bundled into the menu. Otherwise, it more resembles one of the many ancillaries restaurants supply in order to get you to order off that menu. Ancillaries that are often the biggest driver of expenses: location, wait staff, ambiance, etc are all things you receive without paying for them. But they are, of course, meant to drive you towards spending on the menu, which is the mechanism by which they get revenue from you.

      Log in to Reply
      • Garrett says:
        May 18, 2020 at 6:53 am

        If they were to sell them, there’d probably be a bunch of accounting regulations which need to be followed, which are non-zero. There’s also the social expectation as well. If this is something they give away for free when present, it’s very easy to simply say “sorry, we don’t have any” and have the customer leave. But once you start charging for them there may become an expectation of availability.

        Log in to Reply
    • Tenacious D says:
      May 17, 2020 at 6:22 pm

      There are very few byproducts that are completely worthless and comparatively many that are worth less than the cost of transporting them even a nominal distance. Free really means that the recipient covers the cost of transportation (and the producer additionally saves on storage and disposal costs). Basically your supply and demand curves need to account for implicit parts of the price (notably transportation) not just the explicit transaction.

      Log in to Reply
      • Loriot says:
        May 17, 2020 at 6:37 pm

        And some even cost money to dispose of, so giving them away saves the business money.

        Log in to Reply
        • Tenacious D says:
          May 17, 2020 at 6:40 pm

          Exactly. Having a dumpster hauled off and replaced isn’t free.

          Log in to Reply
      • Tenacious D says:
        May 17, 2020 at 6:39 pm

        Note that I’m looking at this from the perspective of larger operations than a typical restaurant. Here are a few interesting examples:
        – craft breweries will often allow a local farmer to take their spent grains to use as animal feed
        – when it comes to large fuel ethanol plants, however, distillers’ dried grains (ddg) is a commodity they sell
        – occasionally you hear about people with DIY biodiesel set-ups that go around collecting used fryer grease from restaurants to power their vehicles
        – rendering plants will collect byproducts from slaughterhouses and fish plants; sometimes they charge for this service but I think sometimes they also end up paying for the feedstock they need

        Log in to Reply
    • Lambert says:
      May 17, 2020 at 7:01 pm

      In civilised parts of the world, they give you the fish wi’ bits of the batter that’s fallen off in the fryer.

      Log in to Reply
    • Thegnskald says:
      May 18, 2020 at 11:51 am

      An interesting related case: The amount of hide produced as a byproduct of beef consumption far outstrips demand.

      Now, there’s an intermediate process – tanning – which produces a good which is valuable. But the demand for properly cured leather isn’t sufficiently high to consume all the leather that could be produced. The current market “solution” is that many (although still not all) hides are partially tanned, producing low-quality “leather”, which is sufficiently inexpensive to hit some price points.

      Which is why cheap leather goods tend to disintegrate pretty quickly, and which is often disguised as higher-quality leather by other practices, such as coating the leather in a thin layer of another material.

      Log in to Reply
      • Iago the Yerfdog says:
        May 18, 2020 at 8:14 pm

        That’s fascinating. In that case, I’m curious how much tanners pay for hide. It seems like the price should be around the neighborhood of “Come and pick it up.”

        Log in to Reply
      • baconbits9 says:
        May 19, 2020 at 5:30 am

        Semi-related: Worm castings sell for ~$2 a pound and restaurants/coffee shops/grocery stores will set aside their waste for worm farmers for free despite it having economic value to them.

        Log in to Reply
    • Jakub Łopuszański says:
      May 18, 2020 at 2:14 pm

      Related question: how should you set prices for DRM-protected downloadable art like mp3 or movies which you can “produce” in infinite amount at the cost of internet transfer and hosting?

      Log in to Reply
      • Iago the Yerfdog says:
        May 18, 2020 at 8:09 pm

        Related, sure, but not the same. Copies aren’t produced as a byproduct of doing something they were going to do anyway.

        EDIT: In this particular case, it seems like you’d have a declining supply curve, representing the amortization of the initial production costs across the increasing number copies sold. That doesn’t mean zero price, because the demand curve can be steeper than the supply curve and thus still intersect it.

        Log in to Reply
  65. broblawsky says:
    May 17, 2020 at 5:02 pm

    Why does dropout regularization work better than ridge/LASSO regularization for computer vision applications? My understanding is that dropout regularization works by introducing random “noise” to the neural network, preventing the network from relying too heavily on any one feature or pattern. Why is this more useful than ridge/LASSO regularization, which accomplishes largely the same thing without randomness?

    Also, is this related in some way to the visual “noise” Scott mentions in this post? I know that drawing close comparisons between neural networks and actual brains is usually a mistake, but the two phenomena sound vaguely similar.

    Log in to Reply
    • LudwigNagasena says:
      May 17, 2020 at 5:50 pm

      Dropout is “smart” ridge regularization that prioritazies important features. See Wager, S., Wang, S., & Liang, P. S. (2013). Dropout training as adaptive regularization.

      Log in to Reply

  67. Dragor says:
    May 17, 2020 at 4:37 pm

    So a couple weeks ago, I posted asking for organization advice, and received persuasive recommendations that I use bullet journal. I (and recently my wife) have since started bullet journaling, and I am finding it useful for having a record of what I have done recently and what I intend to do in a given day, but I think I am only scraping the surface of its potential. I don’t really use collections yet, and I haven’t really figured out the monthly log or future log; I basically just use the daily logger.

    Anybody have any anecdata regarding bulletjournaling, good collections tips, people whom they have found it helpful to emulate?

    Log in to Reply
    • a real dog says:
      May 18, 2020 at 3:11 am

      Being one of the recommenders, I’m happy that it’s working for you.

      I think the biggest tip is to really ensure there is a “cut off point” before which you have no loose ends. If you’re using the vanilla method that would probably be the start of the current month. You need to be completely sure that you reviewed the previous month’s entries during migration, scanned for open items and marked them as done/abandoned/migrated. The feeling of trust that everything is taken care of is 80% of the method’s appeal.

      Log in to Reply
      • Dragor says:
        May 18, 2020 at 2:52 pm

        So given that most tasks I put directly into a day rather than into my month and then from my month to the day, I would flip through my past month’s daily logs?

        Log in to Reply
  68. albatross11 says:
    May 17, 2020 at 4:25 pm

    Alex Tabarrok (of MR fame) proposes how to get out from under the pandemic.

    ISTM that the pandemic has demonstrated a lot of ways our society has ossified and built up rules at so many levels/jurisdictions that it’s almost impossible to adapt quickly to any new thing in a lot of normal life. Like, suppose a restaurant wants to adapt to Covid-19 by moving most or all its tables outside with umbrellas, maybe expanding out into its parking lot. I bet it runs into five or six regulatory hassles involving permitting/zoning, fire code, liquor control, etc., that make this change a huge hassle. And that’s true for *so much* of the world.

    We’re paying a price for this lack of flexibiltiy all the time, but it’s usually hidden. Covid-19 exposes this inflexibility and its costs.

    Log in to Reply
    • Matt M says:
      May 18, 2020 at 8:35 am

      And yet somehow, when it came time for the state to shut down the economy, it all happened instantly and frictionlessly. People just shouted “emergency powers” and it all just happened. No adaptation necessary.

      Log in to Reply
      • albatross11 says:
        May 18, 2020 at 8:50 am

        The state could shut down the bars, but it turned out to be really hard for breweries to make hand sanitizer without running afoul of several different levels of regulation.

        Log in to Reply
  69. Aapje says:
    May 17, 2020 at 4:25 pm

    Video showing what you’d see if rockets were transparent.

    Log in to Reply
    • Neike Taika-Tessaro says:
      May 18, 2020 at 1:34 am

      This was really lovely to look at. Thank you for sharing it!

      Log in to Reply
      • albatross11 says:
        May 18, 2020 at 7:14 am

        +1

        Log in to Reply
      • nkurz says:
        May 18, 2020 at 8:07 am

        @Neike Taika-Tessaro and @albatross11 and @Aapje:

        What did you find interesting about this video? I watched the first half, and stopped because I didn’t think I was getting much out of it: some rockets use liquid propellants, some use solid, stages drop away at different times. Is there another level of information that I’m missing, or was this the interesting part?

        Since I’m taking up space anyway, one part I didn’t understand is why the top stage of the left-most rocket “launches” from the rest at 3:15. What’s happening here?

        Log in to Reply
        • Lambert says:
          May 18, 2020 at 8:43 am

          That’s the launch escape system jetissoning.

          If there’s any kind of catastrophic failure before the Saturn V rocket reaches an altitude of 90km, the command module that contains the astronauts detaches from the rest of the rocket and the launch escape rockets fire. This pulls the crew away from the rest of the rocket faster than it can explode. test flight footage

          Above 90km, they have a different abort mode where the service module uses its rocket to fly clear of any explosion. Because the launch escape system is just extra weight at that point, it is jetissoned. This is similar to what a soyuz did recently.

          Log in to Reply
          • Jake R says:
            May 18, 2020 at 9:02 am

            This pulls the crew away from the rest of the rocket faster than it can explode.

            Wouldn’t this turn the crew to mush about as effectively as the explosion?

          • noyann says:
            May 18, 2020 at 9:06 am

            The danger is not in the g, apparently, but in the shrapnel hitting vital components.

          • John Schilling says:
            May 18, 2020 at 9:28 am

            Traditional rocket propellant combinations, particularly those on the Saturn V, can’t actually detonate because the fuel and oxidizer start in separate places and are in any event immiscible (the liquid temperature ranges don’t even overlap). They can still explode, which a broader term than “detonate”, but it’s a slow-motion explosion limited to the rate at which fuel and oxidizer from separate tanks can meet and react at the interface surface. And, as noyann notes, they can scatter jagged rocket-bits across a broad area, but not the sort of high-velocity fragments you get from e.g. an exploding shell.

            Partial exception to this in solid rockets, which premix the fuel and oxidizer, but usually that’s done at a coarse enough level that you still can’t get a detonation. The exceptions, so far haven’t been used for manned space flight.

            So, possible to escape if you’re smart about it. For the really ballsy version, there’s always Gemini, which used ejection seats rather than trying to pull the capsule clear. Ejection seats set up to do a quick turn and twenty-G burn to clear the fireball. Theoretically survivable, but barely so and fortunately never used operationally.

          • habu71 says:
            May 18, 2020 at 2:09 pm

            @John Schilling
            Does this mean that the N1 rockets didn’t detonate either?

          • Lambert says:
            May 18, 2020 at 2:31 pm

            No, those are LOX BLEVEs followed by deflagrations.
            It’s only a detonation if the flame front is moving faster than the speed of sound.

          • John Schilling says:
            May 18, 2020 at 2:40 pm

            Does this mean that the N1 rockets didn’t detonate either?

            I have a secondary source in English pointing to a primary source in Russian, indicating that the second (and largest) N1 explosion was “only” 4-5 tons TNT equivalent from several hundred tons of propellant whose raw energy density was roughly double that of TNT. So, big explosion in the colloquial sense, with plenty of fire, but any formal detonation was a tiny fraction of the total event.

        • Neike Taika-Tessaro says:
          May 18, 2020 at 8:59 am

          I think you’ve got it covered. The video gives me the same kind of pleasure any good infographic giving me information would give me, even if I already had some of the data (see e.g. Information Is Beautiful). The video shows me more of what’s going on than just watching a rocket launch would, and it shows me more of what’s going on that if I just learnt “this stage detaches at point x” and “this much fuel is in the tanks” (especially latter, given that I am certainly one of the many humans who are terrible at visualising volume), in the sense that the mental work I would be spending to visualise these things is lifted from me. It also gives me a good feel of how long it takes to actually reach space (which I’ve indulged in before, largely from Space X footage, but if I hadn’t, it might be new to me), and it’s interesting to see how the progression of how quickly (or not) the fuel burns (rather than just the ignition and the point of fuel exhaustion).

          That might not be what you were asking, to be fair, but it’s how I took the question. 🙂

          Regarding the Saturn V, I’m no expert, but from reading up on it this was the launch escape system; and once you hit the point where that is no longer the preferred way to recover from problems, you might as well ditch the weight? (Possibly you need to ditch it so the other modes can do their thing?) Someone else please correct me. Oh, good, this was covered by Lambert while I was writing. 😀

          Log in to Reply
          • nkurz says:
            May 18, 2020 at 12:54 pm

            > That might not be what you were asking, to be fair, but it’s how I took the question

            You answered exactly what I was asking. Thank you!

        • Aapje says:
          May 18, 2020 at 4:00 pm

          @nkurz

          Part of my answer would be the same as Neike’s. However, I think that you also missed a lot of things, like:
          – The lower throttling of the middle rocket on Falcon Heavy
          – The rings between the stages on Saturn V that remain attached for a while
          – The lesser efficiency of the Saturn rocket engine
          – The escape system mentioned by others
          – How low the Tesla car actually stayed
          – How the Space Launch System separates most of parts really late, including the escape system
          – The changes in the exhaust plume, including substantial overexpansion at higher altitudes
          – The burn channel in the solid state rockets widens as the fuel burns.

          Log in to Reply
    • John Schilling says:
      May 18, 2020 at 8:55 am

      It’s a nice and potentially enlightening visualization, but some of my colleagues have found a couple of issues with it. The Falcon Heavy seems to shut down too early for a “real time” visualization, reaching parking orbit in five minutes and change compared to eight minutes in reality. And, perhaps more important from a visualization perspective, it shows the staging events occurring with way too much fuel remaining in the tanks. Launch vehicles typically burn to less than 1% residual propellant in the first stage at separation.

      Meanwhile, you’ve all played with the SpaceX docking simulator, right?

      Log in to Reply
      • Neike Taika-Tessaro says:
        May 18, 2020 at 9:10 am

        Thanks for this! Always good to read corrections. (And that simulator is really neat! I had not seen it before. Thank you for linking it.)

        Log in to Reply
      • Lambert says:
        May 18, 2020 at 9:12 am

        Is the relative timing of the SLS and STS SRB separation correct?
        I suppose that, given they burn from the inside outwards, adding an extra segment won’t make it burn for any longer.

        And the Dragon simulator needs a timer for speedruns. I didn’t spend hundreds of hours failing at docking in KSP for nothing.

        Log in to Reply
        • John Schilling says:
          May 18, 2020 at 12:04 pm

          Is the relative timing of the SLS and STS SRB separation correct? I suppose that, given they burn from the inside outwards, adding an extra segment won’t make it burn for any longer.

          Pretty much this. The extra segment I think actually makes it burn out a little bit faster, because you need to cast the grains with a slightly larger core to handle the extra flow and thus the propellant part isn’t quite as thick, but it’s a minor effect and they may have just ignored it.

  70. Aapje says:
    May 17, 2020 at 4:24 pm

    Having to learn all these Dutch fixed expressions is the only reason why the Dutch haven’t conquered the world yet…we’re too busy

    ‘Vechten tegen de bierkaai’ = Fighting against the beer quay

    Fighting a losing battle aka fighting a battle that was hopeless from the start. This expression refers to the fighting prowess of the men who unloaded beer kegs from ships in Amsterdam. Back then, the lower classes would organize bare-knuckled fighting competitions and the workers from the beer quay were known to be undefeatable.

    ‘In de pan gehakt’ = Chopped in the pan

    Defeated comprehensively. Not limited to war, but can be used for sports/games.

    ‘Inmaken’ = preserving/pickling

    Same meaning as the previous.

    ‘Uit een ander vaatje tappen’ = Tapping a different keg

    Making a significant change.

    ‘Bont en blauw (slaan)’ = (Beating) variegated and blue

    (Beating someone) black and blue. This may have started off as ‘blond and blauw’ (blond and blue), where blond referred to a yellowish blue in the 17th century (they referred to blond hair as yellow). However, as ‘bont en blauw’ was also used in the 17 century, it’s possible that both expressions developed in parallel, rather than one from the other.

    ‘in/onder de blote lucht’ = in/under the nude air

    Being directly exposed to air/the elements. For example, you can sleep under the nude air if you sleep outside without a tent. You can let a wound heal in the nude air, if you don’t use a band aid.

    This is a very interesting inversion, where the adjective is applied to the air, while it really applies to (part of) a person or thing that is nude, not the air.

    Log in to Reply
    • Majuscule says:
      May 17, 2020 at 8:05 pm

      I never heard most of these! I never learned Dutch past some cursory phrases but loved learning expressions like this. My husband and I will still toss a few Dutch phrases around, and my daughter hears “Wij zijn niet van suiker” all the time.

      Log in to Reply
    • Tarpitz says:
      May 18, 2020 at 1:53 am

      This is a very interesting inversion, where the adjective is applied to the air, while it really applies to (part of) a person or thing that is nude, not the air.

      The general term for this is a transferred epithet.

      Log in to Reply

  • Jane Street is a quantitative trading firm with a focus on technology and collaborative problem solving. We're always hiring talented programmers, traders, and researchers and have internships and fulltime positions in New York, London, and Hong Kong. No background in finance required.

    Beeminder's an evidence-based willpower augmention tool that collects quantifiable data about your life, then helps you organize it into commitment mechanisms so you can keep resolutions. They've also got a blog about what they're doing here

    Substack is a blogging site that helps writers earn money and readers discover articles they'll like.

    The Effective Altruism newsletter provides monthly updates on the highest-impact ways to do good and help others.

    Giving What We Can is a charitable movement promoting giving some of your money to the developing world or other worthy causes. If you're interested in this, consider taking their Pledge as a formal and public declaration of intent.

    Seattle Anxiety Specialists are a therapy practice helping people overcome anxiety and related mental health issues (eg GAD, OCD, PTSD) through evidence based interventions and self-exploration. Check out their free anti-anxiety guide here

    .

    The Charter Cities Institute is working on ways governments can set up special zones with unique legal institutions. Learn more about how this could help tackle problems from global poverty to climate change.

    B4X is a free and open source developer tool that allows users to write apps for Android, iOS, and more.

    Norwegian founders with an international team on a mission to offer the equivalent of a Norwegian social safety net globally available as a membership. Currently offering travel medical insurance for nomads, and global health insurance for remote teams.

    MealSquares is a "nutritionally complete" food that contains a balanced diet worth of nutrients in a few tasty easily measurable units. Think Soylent, except zero preparation, made with natural ingredients, and looks/tastes a lot like an ordinary scone.

    The COVID-19 Forecasting Project at the University of Oxford is making advanced pandemic simulations of 150+ countries available to the public, and also offer pro-bono forecasting services to decision-makers.

    Dr. Laura Baur is a psychiatrist with interests in literature review, reproductive psychiatry, and relational psychotherapy; see her website for more. Note that due to conflict of interest she doesn't treat people in the NYC rationalist social scene.

    Support Slate Star Codex on Patreon. I have a day job and SSC gets free hosting, so don't feel pressured to contribute. But extra cash helps pay for contest prizes, meetup expenses, and me spending extra time blogging instead of working.

    80,000 Hours researches different problems and professions to help you figure out how to do as much good as possible. Their free career guide show you how to choose a career that's fulfilling and maximises your contribution to solving the world's most pressing problems.

    AISafety.com hosts a Skype reading group Wednesdays at 19:45 UTC, reading new and old articles on different aspects of AI Safety. We start with a presentation of a summary of the article, and then discuss in a friendly atmosphere.

    Altruisto is a browser extension so that when you shop online, a portion of the money you pay goes to effective charities (no extra cost to you). Just install an extension and when you buy something, people in poverty will get medicines, bed nets, or financial aid.

    Metaculus is a platform for generating crowd-sourced predictions about the future, especially science and technology. If you're interested in testing yourself and contributing to their project, check out their questions page
